metadata.sermon_title: 4. Christ vs. Adam: Kosovo and Beyond
metadata.sermon_start_end: Last Tuesday I was sitting at a picnic table overlooking Middle Cove in Essex. As the snowy egrets made their stately way across the shimmering sheet of water, I went through my file of clippings about Kosovo. [...] Now we are ready to hear our Lord Jesus say, 'Let your light so shine before everyone, that they may see your good works and glorify your Father who is in heaven' (Matt. 5:16). AMEN.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon centers on the Adam-Christ typology of Romans 5. It correctly identifies the 'nowhere else' quality of the text: the radical, objective shift from one corporate identity to another. However, it dilutes this specificity by pulling in Jeremiah, Matthew, and Romans 7, which risks turning the sermon into a general speech about 'the human condition'.
quotes: This is a phenomenon to which Paul assigns the name of 'Adam.'
Paul wants to make sure we understand this; in our text for this morning, he says it in five different ways.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Resist the urge to harmonize the text with Romans 7. Focus exclusively on the forensic and corporate 'much more' of Romans 5 to avoid a general psychological discourse.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher understands the theological structure of Paul's argument but provides little to no historical-critical or linguistic depth. There is no mention of the Greek nuances of 'dikaioma' or the specific context of the Roman house churches. It relies more on Augustine and Freud than on technical exegesis.
quotes: Augustine found Paul’s writings to be a precise account of the human condition
Whether you believe that Adam was a real person or not makes no difference
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the specific historical tension in Rome between Jewish and Gentile Christians to ground the 'all men' of the text in its original context.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: This is the sermon's greatest strength. The application is brutally concrete, avoiding 'general truths.' The use of the Kosovo crisis and the specific story of the Gypsy boy in the refugee camp makes the 'misery' of Adam tangible and terrifyingly current.
quotes: Macedonia’s camps are sweltering caldrons of hate
the Foxwoods addict who gambles away his family’s livelihood
the enraged mother whom I saw yesterday dragging her screaming tot across the supermarket parking lot
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application of 'reigning in life' is as concrete as the application of 'misery' was.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon successfully avoids the 'block' structure. It moves fluidly between the newspaper clippings and the Pauline text. The hearer is 'expounded' through the lens of the Kosovo mob.
quotes: What we see illustrated here is that victims can become victimizers in a blink. Thus it has been throughout the millennia... Paul, in Romans, paints one of the most comprehensive pictures...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: The transition to the 'Christ' section feels slightly more detached/lecturing than the 'Adam' section; maintain the narrative tension throughout.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The three parts are clearly present. Misery is handled with exceptional seriousness (the mob). Redemption is external (the 'intervention from beyond'). Gratitude is illustrated by the story of Calvin Johnson.
quotes: undone the reign of sin, loosed the grip of death
Bitterness will destroy you. Now I just need a job.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: The 'gratitude' section (Calvin Johnson) risks becoming a moral example of human willpower rather than a result of the Spirit's work.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon addresses the 'lostness' of man in time (the cycle of hate) and eternity ('our case is terminal'). It rejects the 'American theology' of free will, emphasizing that man is a captive. However, the 'narrow way' is less clearly defined than the 'broad way'.
quotes: The American answer to every theological and ethical dilemma is 'freedom of the will.'... Paul’s urgent message to us in Romans is that the law of sin is much stronger than we are.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Explicitly state the consequence of remaining in 'Adam' versus being in 'Christ' to sharpen the 'two ways' distinction.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the telos. The sermon correctly identifies that only an 'intervention from beyond' (God in Christ) can break the cycle. It maintains the 'extra nos' (outside of us) character of grace.
quotes: God’s action in the death and resurrection of our Lord Jesus Christ has reversed the sin of Adam
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Deepen the 'two natures' aspect; show how Christ’s human obedience (as the second Adam) is specifically what achieves the acquittal.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At over 2,000 words, the sermon meets Dekker's requirement for breadth. It takes the time to let the 'misery' sink in before offering the 'redemption'.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: None; the length is adequate for the complexity of the subject.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon is a strong example of contemporary preaching that takes the 'misery' of the human condition seriously. It falls short in technical exegesis (Thesis 2) and occasionally drifts into general psychological categories (Freud/Augustine) rather than sticking strictly to the unique logic of Romans 5. However, its concrete application and Christocentric focus are traceable and effective.
strengths: Radical concreteness in describing human sin through the Kosovo conflict.
Strong rejection of 'moralism' and 'free will' in favor of Pauline captivity/liberation.
Effective use of narrative to illustrate the transition from Adam to Christ.
weaknesses: Insufficient use of original languages or historical-critical exegesis.
Tendency to harmonize different biblical voices (Jeremiah, Matthew) at the expense of the specific text's uniqueness.
Heavy reliance on secular/psychological authorities (Freud, NY Review of Books) which occasionally overshadows the biblical exposition.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a sermon in the sense of Dekker's definition. It successfully recreates the Bible into a 'new, current, proclamatory word' and respects the 3-2-1 rule, though it would benefit from more rigorous exegetical 'labor' in the study.
